sections.title: Westmorland and Furness' employment, unemployment and economic inactivity - ONS
sections.description: How Westmorland and Furness (E06000064) compares with the North West and Great Britain across employment-related statistics

sections.title: Employment, unemployment and economic inactivity in Westmorland and Furness
sections.standfirst: How Westmorland and Furness compares with the North West and Great Britain across employment-related statistics
sections.label: Select a different local authority

sections.content:
Employment in Westmorland and Furness has slightly increased compared with the previous year. Westmorland and Furness' employment rate was higher than across the North West as a whole in the year ending March 2023.

Go to employment rate section ↓

The unemployment rate in Westmorland and Furness was 1.7% in the year ending March 2023. Unemployed people are looking for work and able to start work.

Go to unemployment rate section ↓

Claimant Count was slightly lower in August 2023 compared with the previous year. The Claimant Count measures the number of people who are claiming unemployment-related benefits.

Go to Claimant Count section ↓

Economic inactivity has decreased since the previous year. These are people who are neither employed nor seeking work.

Go to economic inactivity section ↓

Local authority estimates are more variable than national or regional figures and less precise. This is because there are fewer survey respondents living within each area.

Estimates of the number of people who are employed, unemployed and economically inactive may be under- or over-estimates. This is because of uncertainty over local population sizes within the survey.

Estimates of employment and economic inactivity are based on the Annual Population Survey. Unemployment estimates are modelled to improve their precision compared to those based only on responses provided via the Annual Population Survey. These data are all national statistics.

The Claimant Count is based on administrative data from the benefits system. These data are experimental statistics.

sections.title: Employment in Westmorland and Furness has slightly increased compared with the previous year
sections.content:
Westmorland and Furness' employment rate was higher than across the North West as a whole in the year ending March 2023.

Of people aged 16 to 64 years living in Westmorland and Furness, 76.3% were employed in the year ending March 2023. This is a slight increase compared with the year ending March 2022 when the local rate was 75.9%.

Across the North West in the year ending March 2023, 73.6% of people aged 16 to 64 years were employed. This was slightly higher compared with the previous year, when 73.1% of people were employed.

sections.title: Employment rates of areas in the North West
sections.subtitle: Among those aged 16 to 64 years (%), year ending March 2012 to year ending March 2023
sections.footer: Source: Annual Population Survey from the Office for National Statistics
sections.note: Figures are based on a small number of survey responses in each area and are less precise than national or regional estimates. Ranking, and changes in ranking, may be the result of sampling variability.

sections.content:
Overall, there were 104,000 people aged 16 and over in Westmorland and Furness who were employed in the year ending March 2023. This is slightly up from the previous year, when there were 101,000 people aged 16 and over who were employed.

Estimates of how many people are employed, unemployed and economically inactive may be under- or over-estimates. This is because of uncertainty over local population sizes within our survey data.

sections.title: Unemployment rate in Westmorland and Furness was 1.7% in the year ending March 2023
sections.content:
Unemployment estimates are modelled to improve their precision compared to those based only on responses provided via the Annual Population Survey.

Around 2,800 people aged 16 and over in Westmorland and Furness were unemployed in the year ending March 2023. This is a rate of 1.7%.

Across the North West, from the year ending March 2022 to the year ending March 2023, there was a decrease in the unemployment rate from 4.4% to 3.9%.

Year on year, the number of people unemployed in the North West fell from around 157,000 to around 138,000 over the same period.

Unemployment across Great Britain dropped between the year ending March 2022 and the year ending March 2023, from around 1,350,000 people (4.1%) to around 1,200,000 (3.6%).

Unemployed people are those without jobs who are actively seeking work and available to take up a job. Some jobless people may not seek work or be able to work for various reasons, such as retirement, sickness, or study, and are called "economically inactive".

This means that the employment rate and the unemployment rate can both go up at the same time as people move into the labour market and become job seekers.

The unemployment rate is the number of unemployed people out of everyone "economically active" in the labour market, that is, everyone who is employed or looking for work. The employment rate is out of the working-age population including "economically inactive" people.

sections.title: Claimant Count in Westmorland and Furness was slightly lower than in the previous year
sections.content:
The Claimant Count is an experimental statistic that measures the number of people who are claiming unemployment-related benefits.

The Claimant Count in Westmorland and Furness was 2555 in August 2023, down from August 2022, when there were 2670 claimants.

The proportion of people aged 16 to 64 years in Westmorland and Furness who were claiming unemployment-related benefits was 1.9% in August 2023, a slight decrease compared with August 2022 when it was 2.0%.

sections.title: Claimant Count (%) for areas in the North West
sections.subtitle: Among those aged 16 to 64 years, August 2013 to August 2023
sections.footer: Source: Claimant Count from Department for Work and Pensions

sections.title: Economic inactivity has decreased in Westmorland and Furness compared with the previous year
sections.content:
Around 26,700 people or 21.2% of the population aged 16 to 64 years in Westmorland and Furness were "economically inactive" in the year ending March 2023. This compares with around 28,500 people (22.6%) in the year ending March 2022.

People are classed as "economically inactive" if they are not in employment but don't meet the criteria for being "unemployed". This means they have not been seeking work within the previous four weeks or were unable to start work within the next two weeks. Common reasons include being retired, looking after the home or family or being temporarily or long-term sick and disabled.

Economic inactivity in Westmorland and Furness is lower than across the North West.

Across the North West, 23.5% of people aged 16 to 64 years were economically inactive during the year ending March 2023, around the same rate as the year ending March 2022 when 23.4% were economically inactive.

Overall in Great Britain, 21.6% of people aged 16 to 64 years were economically inactive, compared with 21.5% in the previous year.

sections.title: Economic inactivity in Westmorland and Furness compared with the North West
sections.subtitle: Residents aged 16 to 64 years (%), year ending March 2023
sections.footer: Source: Annual Population Survey from the Office for National Statistics
sections.note: The estimate for Westmorland and Furness is based on a small number of survey responses and is less precise than national or regional estimates. Ranking may be the result of sampling variability.

sections.title: More data about Westmorland and Furness
sections.content:
You can view and download more local labour market data on the Westmorland and Furness area profile page on Nomis.

sections.title: More data on the labour market
sections.content:
The most recent labour market figures for all local authorities are in our associated data release.

You can also read our most recent labour market overview.

Historic data is available on Nomis. For employment and economic inactivity, see estimates from the Annual Population Survey. Data for model-based unemployment and Claimant Count (non-seasonally adjusted) are also available.

sections.title: About this article
sections.content:
The content in this article is generated using semi-automated journalism, based on rules pre-programmed by Office for National Statistics (ONS) staff.

This is a new product in Beta release, intended to improve the accessibility of labour market data at local level. Leave us general feedback or contact the subnational analysis team by emailing subnational@ons.gov.uk.

Articles are not available for Isles of Scilly and City of London, as the survey samples of the resident population are too small.
